column1: https://www.joebucsfan.com/2025/02/josh-grizzard-details-ryan-fitzpatrick-guidance/|Josh Grizzard Details Ryan Fitzpatrick Guidance|There will be a little bit of Fitzmagic in the 2025 Buccaneers offense. No
column2: Baker Mayfield is not growing out his beard. Rookie Bucs offensive coordinator Josh Grizzard was 26 years old when he joined the Miami Dolphins offensive staff as a quality control assistant back in 2017. Two years later
column3: high-mileage NFL veteran QB Ryan Fitzpatrick landed on the Dolphins roster after two seasons with the Bucs. Grizzard told Joe that not only was Fitzpatrick a mentor to him
column4: but Fitzpatrick’s teachings are still part of Grizzard’s approach today. Fitzpatrick recently blessed Grizzard’s promotion on social media. During his visit with The JoeBucsFan Show on WDAE radio
column5: Grizzard described that as “pretty cool” and explained some of Fitzpatrick’s impact on his coaching. “He was huge for me
column6: ” Grizzard said of Fitzpatrick. “I learned so much from him. It might sound odd
column7: the coach learning from the player [in Miami]. At that time
column8: I’d only been in the NFL for a handful of years and he had played for so many organziations
column9: and he just tried to tell me what he saw good and bad in coordinators and position coaches — and trying to eliminate things that are losing. He was just a wealth of knowledge and that was on the personnel side of it
column10: and just on the field a competitor
column11: love him to death.” Grizzard went on to say Fitzpatrick gave him a lot of feedback about planning for different scenarios
column13: good and bad practice schemes and more. “[Fitzpatrick] had just seen so much that it was invaluable [guidance] and I still lean on some of those things today
column14: ” Grizzard said.|2025-02-18 11:18:00|277|18|8|Ryan Fitzpatrick|Grizzard learns valuable coaching lessons from Fitzmagic.|5|Mixed sentiments with some positive and negative comments about Fitz and Grizzard.|"{""commenter0"": {""username"": ""HC Grover""

column1: https://www.joebucsfan.com/2025/02/the-war-on-ben-bredeson/|The War On Ben Bredeson|Joe sometimes doesn’t understand where the disconnect began or how it evolved but we’ve now boarded the crazy train — with apologies to Ozzy Osbourne. What Joe expects and sees from offensive line play is truly a different prism from what others expect and see. Millions Of People Living As Foes. Joe is not sitting here trying to make the case that Bucs free agent guard Ben Bredeson is the next John Hannah (look him up). He’s not. But the guy certainly is not Garrett “Whoops!” Gilkey. Someone will have to point out to Joe how Bredeson was a “major liability” unless someone has a fully different definition of “liability.” Some media sells it and you live the role. The Bucs had the third-best offense last season with the fourth-best run game. How exactly can a team pull this off with a “liability” at left guard? A team doesn’t. But don’t tell that to Walter Cherepinsky

column3: you would think Cherepinsky was typing about Oniel Cousins. Guard: Ben Bredeson was a major liability on Tampa Bay’s offensive front

column6: Bredeson was playing next to a rookie center. If he was that awful
column7: then Graham Barton would have been exposed as well. There are positions on the Bucs and starters who drag the team down. Bredeson is not one of them. column1: https://www.joebucsfan.com/2025/02/espn-bucs-wont-use-a-franchise-tag-again-on-chris-godwin/|ESPN: Bucs Won’t Use A Franchise Tag (Again) On Chris Godwin|The reason why most people — including Joe — have never mentioned Chris Godwin getting franchise tagged is that if Bucs AC/DC-loving general manager Jason Licht tagged Godwin for the third time
column2: Team Glazer might start wondering who spiked Licht’s coffee. If a player is tagged by a team three times
column3: per the NFL’s bargaining agreement with the NFLPA
column4: that player would have to be paid 144 percent of his previous season’s salary. Thus
column5: Godwin’s 2025 salary under a third tag would be in the $29 million ballpark. The Bucs have already tagged Godwin twice. But
column7: Licht just might have a lapse of reason. Per Jenna Laine of ESPN
column8: her Bucs sources told her as much as the Bucs want Godwin back
column9: paying him $29 million is unthinkable. So no
column10: the Bucs won’t tag Godwin as tag season gets underway today. … They used the tag as a placeholder the last time Godwin was a free agent (in 2022)
column11: and they used it on him in 2021
column12: so this would be his third time being tagged — therefore it would have to be a 144% raise
column13: and I’m told there is “no chance” of that happening. They’ll do what it takes to re-sign him as a free agent. The Bucs are unlikely to tag anyone. At the price and salary cap hit to tag a player
column14: he pretty much has to be one of the top players at his position. No pending Bucs free agent is close to that
column15: with the exception of Godwin. If fact
column16: no team in the NFL is expected to use the tag this season. The tag window is open from today through March 4.
